results.title: Desert locust
results.brief_description: An account of the life cycle, structure and behaviour of the desert locust. Follows the development of the locust through the five hopper stages when the insect goes through a state of immobility, explaining that this is the best time to destroy it. The most widely used method of destruction is hand dispersed poison mixed with a bait such as wheat bran.

results.title: Desert farming
results.creator_credit: Quartet Films, West, Lou Lilly and Arthur G. Evans
results.brief_description: Describes the conservation approaches and the modern technology used by scientists to convert deserts into blooming farmlands; how we have learned to bring water for irrigation, leech the soil of unwanted chemicals, and provide proper drainage. Shows machinery used, crops grown, harvesting and packaging.

results.title: Desert ecology
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau and Walter H Berlet
results.brief_description: Deals with plants and animals living in a hot desert climate. Discusses the adaptations which enable them to withstand the long dry periods. Also shows daily living patterns of animals which enable them to survive in the great heat. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Desert Conquest
results.creator_credit: Australian Instructional Films and Lex Halliday
results.brief_description: The story of how the Australian Mutual Provident Society, by a scheme of mass clearing and scientific development transformed over a quarter of a million acres of desert land in South Australia into rich pasture holdings. Shows how the land was cleared and how the men and their families who worked on this project eventually settled on the reclaimed soil on farms of their own.

results.title: Desert cargo
results.creator_credit: Vickers Films, British Information Services, Leslie Sansom and A Vickers
results.brief_description: For the transportation of liquefied natural gas from Algeria to Britain the engineers of Vickers shipbuilding undertake at the Barrow Shipyard the building of a highly specialised tanker. The initial research, construction and testing that led up to the launching of the “Methane Princess” are set against the background of the scheme to bring a new source of energy to Britain and pioneer a new world industry

results.title: Desert bloom
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Michael Hausman and Eugene Corr
results.brief_description: Set in Las Vegas at the time of the first atom bomb tests in 1951, this powerful drama examines the life of a struggling middle-class Nevada family, seen through the eyes of 13 year old Rose Chismore (Annabeth Gish). Finding life difficult with her war-scarred father (Jon Voight), Rose forms a close bond with her flamboyant Aunt Starr (Ellen Barkin) whose friendship comes at a critical time.

results.title: Describing an incident
results.brief_description: A group of students describe an incident. In the first instance a poor description is given - a girl trying to describe how a friend’s father nearly missed a train, wanders off into irrelevant detail and fails to capture interest. Another girl, describing the same incident, creates interest with an ordered and well-presented account.

results.title: Descent
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Tom Daly, Desmond Dew, Giles Walker and Paul Cowan
results.brief_description: Descent is a film about David Murray, a member of Canada’s National Ski Team. It shows the less glamorous aspects of training for the World Cup Downhill race, the tension prior to the event, and Murray’s mixed feelings when it is all over. The camera records a spectacular slow-motion fall, and speeds that would not appeal to your average highway patrol. Murray comes across as a skillful, courageous and dedicated athlete, and a very likeable guy at that. Sound film without commentary. Film without words.

results.title: Descendant of Genghiz Khan = Potomok Chingis-Khana
results.brief_description: Better known under the title “Storm over Asia”, this exotic film is a remarkable drama of British Imperial intrigue in Mongolia in the civil war days of 1920. Valeri Inkijinov plays a young Mongolian trapper ostracised from his village after he is cheated out of a valuable fox fur by a European trader. Becoming a Soviet partisan, the trapper is thrust into prominence when it is learned that he is descended from Genghis Khan. The occupying English army (identified as the White Russian army in foreign prints of the film) puts the trapper in charge of a puppet Mongolian government. By film’s end, however, the “puppet” has cut the strings in a spectacular fashion. In Russian with English subtitles.

results.title: Desalting the seas
results.creator_credit: Oak Ridge National Laboratory and Stephen Sinichak
results.brief_description: Describes the various methods of purifying salt water through the use of nuclear energy, with particular emphasis on nuclear electric desalting plants which produce large amounts of power as well as pure water. Describes the growing shortage of water in a famine-threatened world of expanding population, and ways to combat this.
